review.title: Non-Gaussian Random Generators in Bacteria Foraging Algorithm for Multiobjective Optimization
review.abstract: Random generators or stochastic engines are a key component in the structure of metaheuristic algorithms. This work investigates the effects of non-Gaussian stochastic engines on the performance of metaheuristics when solving a real-world optimization problem. In this work, the bacteria foraging algorithm (BFA) was employed in tandem with four random generators (stochastic engines). The stochastic engines operate using the Weibull distribution, Gamma distribution, Gaussian distribution and a chaotic mechanism. The two non-Gaussian distributions are the Weibull and Gamma distributions. In this work, the approaches developed were implemented on the real-world multi-objective resin bonded sand mould problem. The Pareto frontiers obtained were benchmarked using two metrics; the hyper volume indicator (HVI) and the proposed Average Explorative Rate (AER) metric. Detail discussions from various perspectives on the effects of non-Gaussian random generators in metaheuristics are provided.
histories: 8 pages; 5 Figures; 6 Tables. Industrial Engineering & Management, 2015
review.COMMENTS: 8 pages; 5 Figures; 6 Tables. Industrial Engineering & Management, 2015

sections.heading: Gaussian distribution
sections.text: A random variable, x-X, distributed with mean, µ and variance, σ2 is called Gaussian or normal distribution if the PDFs are distributed as follows: 21 1 () Exp 22X xG x µ σσ π − = − (7) Gaussian distribution is very general and widely applicable in various fields of study for modeling real random numbers (e.g. Brownian motion [22] and Monte Carlo simulations [23]). In this paper, the standard normal distribution with µ = 0 and σ = 1 is used in the stochastic machine to generate random values in metaheuristics.

sections.heading: Weibull distribution
sections.text: The Weibull distribution function for a random variable x-X is defined as follows: () 1 exp kxW xλ = − − for (0,) x R + ∞ (8), where W (x) is the Weibull distribution, k is the form parameter and λ is the scale parameter. It is necessary that the scale and form parameters for the Weibull distribution (k > 0 and λ > 0) are positive. For λ = 1, the Weibull distribution takes the form of the exponential distribution. It should be noted that the Weibull distributions around it decrease as the value of k increases. In this work, shape and scale parameters are defined in such a way that λ = 1 and k = 1. The Weibull distribution is widespread in areas as microbiology [24], information systems [25] and meteorology [26].

As the standard deviation of the distribution increases, the PDF gradually tilts to the left and becomes cumbersome. Gamma distribution has been successfully used in climatology, insurance claim models and risk analysis [27-29].

sections.heading: Bacteria Foraging Algorithm
sections.text: In the BFA there are four main levels of loops in the technique (chemotaxis, swarming, reproduction and elimination dispersion loops), which are executed iteratively until the total number of iterations is met. sections.heading: Average explorative rate
sections.text: A novel measurement variable, the Average Explorative Rate (AER), is introduced in this thesis to measure the thoroughness of the search operation carried out by the computational technique in the regions of the objective space. AER performs successively online measurements during the execution of the computational technique, which measures the quantity of the search region covered on average by the computational technique at each iteration. The proposed AER can be calculated by first determining the deviation of the objective functional values at each iteration: 1 () (n i n i n i n i f x f x δ + − = (16) where () n if x is the objective functional value at the ninth iteration with xi the decision variables. Then the Heaviside Step Function is used to return a value if the deviation is greater than any predefined value, L.0 () 1 nn nif H if L is used in comparison with iteration.

sections.heading: Outlook
sections.text: The introduction of the non-Gaussian approach in the conventional stochastic engine has shown very interesting results. It can be observed in Table 5 and Figure 6 that the W-BFA, which is equipped with a non-Gaussian stochastic motor, outperforms all other approaches used in this work in terms of individual solution and degree of Pareto boundary dominance. However, it is possible that the choice of the non-Gaussian distribution used in the solution method depends on the type of solution landscape, although it is also equipped with a non-Gaussian stochastic motor. Due to this dependence, the effectiveness of the computational approach with a certain type of non-Gaussian stochastic motor may prove advantageous, but it is possible that the choice of the non-Gaussian distribution used in the solution method depends on the type of solution landscape.

metadata.abstractText: Random generators or stochastic engines are a key component in the structure of metaheuristic algorithms. This work investigates the effects of non-Gaussian stochastic engines on the performance of metaheuristics when solving a real-world optimization problem. In this work, the bacteria foraging algorithm (BFA) was employed in tandem with four random generators (stochastic engines). The stochastic engines operate using the Weibull distribution, Gamma distribution, Gaussian distribution and a chaotic mechanism. The two non-Gaussian distributions are the Weibull and Gamma distributions. In this work, the approaches developed were implemented on the real-world multi-objective resin bonded sand mould problem. The Pareto frontiers obtained were benchmarked using two metrics; the hyper volume indicator (HVI) and the proposed Average Explorative Rate (AER) metric. Detail discussions from various perspectives on the effects of non-Gaussian random generators in metaheuristics are provided. *Corresponding author: Ganesan T, School of Chemical Engineering, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, 5005 South Australia, Australia; E-mail: tim.ganesan@gmail.com Received September 29, 2015; Accepted November 27, 2015; Published November 30, 2015 Citation: Ganesan T, Vasant P, Elamvazuthi I (2015) Non-Gaussian Random Generators in Bacteria Foraging Algorithm for Multiobjective Optimization.
